awd_titl_txt: Research Immersive Scholastic Experience in Biology: A Scholarship and Support Program
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, the Research Immersive Scholastic Experience in Biology (RISEbio) program is providing support to low-income students with demonstrated financial need and academic promise to succeed in STEM disciplines at Minnesota State University, Mankato (MSUM).  The project is funding 80 scholarships over five years for students who are pursuing bachelor's degrees in biological sciences.  Participating in research is one of the crucial factors in retaining students in STEM fields.  However, research opportunities are often hard to find for students in the first two years of undergraduate education, especially at comprehensive institutions without a large research community.  To address this need, the Department of Biological Sciences at MSUM will develop and implement a scholarship and support program targeting incoming freshmen.  Eighty students, in four cohorts of 20, will enter the program in their freshman year and will take one research methods course, followed by two semesters of research in Brain and Behavior or Immunity and Cancer.  RISEbio will award freshmen with financial need and academic potential a scholarship that is renewable over three semesters while they take part in the program.  The overall goal of RISEbio is to increase student academic success as measured by first-time pass rates for core courses, discipline retention, and 4- and 5-year graduation rates.  In addition to participating in research, RISEbio students will join learning communities and will be guided by faculty and peer mentors. The research component of RISEbio is designed to provide scholars with an authentic real-world research experience similar to that experienced by students at research-intensive universities, but tailored to fit within the available infrastructure at a primarily undergraduate comprehensive institution such as MSUM.  RISEbio will provide a platform to test how the proposed objectives translate to student persistence and academic success.  
 

Through evaluative and summative assessment, the RISEbio project will enhance our knowledge of how student success in the biological sciences is impacted through first- and second-year scholastic experiences that bridge social integration, mentorship, and technical and professional skill building with an immersive research experience.  Moreover, RISEbio will provide insight on how student academic success is impacted when financial burdens are reduced through a scholarship which supports students during a critical window of adjustment to college.  Lastly, the RISEbio program is modifying existing freshman research programs utilized by research-intensive universities to fit within the available infrastructure of a primarily undergraduate comprehensive institution.  This adaptation provides a foundation for understanding how immersive freshman research experiences in biology impact comprehensive university student outcomes.  By developing and implementing RISEbio initiatives, RISEbio will enhance first-time pass rates for core courses, improve retention, and increase 4- and 5-year graduation rates for low-income, academically motivated students.  The overlapping and integrated nature of the RISEbio objectives provide a catalyst for developing a workforce with professional and technical skills that will ultimately improve student marketability for both post-baccalaureate employment and graduate school.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Program (S-STEM) award to the Department of Biological Sciences at Minnesota State University Mankato (MSU), a primarily undergraduate institution, supported development and implementation of a unique scholarship and support program targeting incoming freshmen, entitled “Research Immersive Scholastic Experience in Biology” (RISEbio). The overall goal of RISEbio was to increase student academic success as measured by first-time pass rates for core courses, discipline retention, and graduation rates for students who a show demonstrated financial need and academic potential. The goals were supported by three complimentary objectives: (1) Increase student social integration and support, (2) Develop student technical and professional skills, and (3) Implement a first-year immersive research program. A major part of RISEbio was to provide participants with research experiences within the confines of available infrastructure at a primarily undergraduate institution. Furthermore, RISEbio provided a platform to test how the proposed objectives translate to student persistence and academic success in the biological sciences.

Under this award, a first-year research experience program was established in the Department of Biological Sciences and the Department of Biochemistry, Chemistry, and Geology. Additionally, a cohort model was shaped and supported by utilizing, in part, an existing learning community structure and embedded peer mentors. Through evaluative and summative assessment, the RISEbio project investigated how student success in the biological sciences is impacted by a first- and second-year scholastic experience that integrates an immersive research experience and bridges social integration, mentorship, and technical and professional skill building. Our studies compared biology and biochemistry majors who were RISEbio participants (89 total, 65 of whom received scholarship funds) to biology non-RISEbio participants who agreed to partake in our study. Our results demonstrate that the RISEbio program supported student academic success based on performance (percent achieved, grade distribution) in introductory science course success (General Biology I and II, General Chemistry I). Cumulative GPA was also generally higher in RISEbio participants, although only significantly increased following semesters 1 and 5. Through survey tools, we observed that the RISEbio program eased the college transition and increased a sense of belonging, scientific motivation, science identity and science values alignment in the scholars. RISEbio also enhanced self-efficacy and the desire to pursue a science career. Lastly, for scholarship eligible students who persisted in the program beyond 2 years, the current graduation rate is 80% and the time to completion is 4.04 years. The overlapping and integrated nature of the RISEbio objectives provided a catalyst for developing workforce driven professional and technical skills that supported positive student outcomes.


Last Modified: 04/30/2024
Modified by: David S Sharlin
